nycTheatreExcerpt: "Is that a reasonable response to aim for when staging the world's most famous weepie? For me, seeing so many young people engaged, it is. Perhaps, as Shakespeare commands in the play's closing speech, they will "Go hence, to have more talk of these sad things." And so what if the production achieves that goal by protecting them from too much unruly feeling, just as the Capulets aimed to protect Juliet? Probably, the Capulets were right."

keyPhrases.quote: But before you wonder whether this production was sponsored by CliffsNotes, with only as much poetry and staying power as an Instagram story, bear in mind that many of the characters are teenagers, and that the play may most usefully be directed at people seeing it for the first time, not the 36th.

llmScore.reasoning: [ensemble-unanimous] | All 3 models agree: Mixed | Claude: The review is genuinely mixed - it critiques the adaptation as simplified ('CliffsNotes', 'Instagram story') and confusing, but defends the approach as appropriate for its young target audience. The tone neither clearly recommends nor discourages attendance. | Gemini: The review acknowledges the production's efforts to engage a younger audience but also points out its unconventional and potentially confusing choices. It neither strongly recommends nor discourages seeing the show. | Kimi: The review text cuts off before delivering a final verdict or clear recommendation. The available portion presents a balanced view: praising the production's accessibility and appeal to young audiences ('adorably', 'formidable toolbox') while criticizing its stripped-down, confusing execution ('indistinguishably', 'barely there Prince'). Without the conclusion, the overall recommendation direction remains ambiguous.

bwwExcerpt: It’s a little slick, though, at least for seen-that adults. The play’s twisty language, expressive of twisty thoughts, is largely untangled but, in the process, flattened. (Gold’s edit brings the running time, not counting intermission, to “the two hours’ traffic of the stage” Shakespeare mentions, but some of that traffic is stop-and-go.) I smiled a lot but never came close to crying.
fullText:
You have a preview view of this article while we are checking your access. When we have confirmed access, the full article content will load.Theater Review

The Broadway revival of “Romeo + Juliet” plays to the TikTok crowd. But maybe that’s a good thing.

Credit...Sara Krulwich/The New York Times

Listen to this article · 6:34 min Learn moreShare full article71By Jesse Green

Who can forget the classic first line of “Romeo and Juliet”: “How y’all doin’ today?”

Well, perhaps not so classic. But as uttered at the start of the play’s 36th Broadway revival, which opened Thursday at Circle in the Square, the words are certainly more welcoming to the production’s youthful target audience than the traditional iambic pentameter ones: “Two households, both alike in dignity.”

Not that there are two households in the director Sam Gold’s rec-room adaptation anyway. Romeo’s parents, along with a clutch of other characters, have been discarded. Juliet’s are both played by one actor, with little more than a change of inflection. And though Kit Connor and Rachel Zegler, the box-office draws, cover just one star-crossed lover each — he a beagly Romeo, she a beamish Juliet — the other eight cast members take on 17 roles, adorably if often indistinguishably. It’s a puppy pile.

But before you wonder whether this production was sponsored by CliffsNotes, with only as much poetry and staying power as an Instagram story, bear in mind that many of the characters are teenagers, and that the play may most usefully be directed at people seeing it for the first time, not the 36th. Certainly Gold has used everything in his formidable toolbox — scissors, hammers, punches, wrenches — to get young people interested in a world that looks more like theirs than Elizabethan London or Renaissance Verona.

So after an energetic preshow, filled with flirting, peacocking and snits of aggression, the story begins with that casual greeting from Gabby Beans, the play’s Chorus. Beans, later a hotheaded Mercutio, a beneficent Friar Lawrence and a barely there Prince Escalus, makes a relatable hype woman, introducing the rest of the cast by first name and telling us whom they’ll be playing. If you’re confused — and even a frequent flier might be — you can consult a program insert that visualizes the Montagues and Capulets as a mood board.

Feeling the groove: Gabby Beans, far right, leading Tommy Dorfman (center), Kit Connor (far back) and other cast members in a dance in Sam Gold’s “Romeo + Juliet” at Circle in the Square.Credit...Sara Krulwich/The New York TimesWe are having trouble retrieving the article content.

showScoreExcerpt:
“The play is thus less terrifying than teenifying — hence the plus sign instead of the ‘and’ in the title.”
